Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Julia L. Stevens of The University of Alabama to conduct a research project, entitled "Biogeography of a marine invasion: Comparison of the red lionfish between the native Indo-Pacific and invaded Atlantic regions," during the summer of 2012 at The National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in Pingtung, Taiwan. The host scientist is Chih-Wei Chang.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is as follows: For the last 25 years, the U.S. Atlantic Coast and the Caribbean Sea have experienced rapid population growth and dispersal of the invasive red lionfish, a venomous fish native to Indo-Pacific waters. Research on the impacts of lionfish on Atlantic and Caribbean reefs has highlighted the urgent need for additional studies on both this invasion and the invader. However, the paucity of research on the ecology of lionfish in their native range remains apparent, and without understanding their ecology in the Indo-Pacific it is impossible to determine what makes this species such a successful invader in the Atlantic and Caribbean. Specifically, this research aims to assess the bacterial communities associated with the external surfaces of lionfish. By examining this host-microbial relationship, a more thorough knowledge of the host organism can be obtained. The objectives of the research in Taiwan are twofold: first, record behavioral and density observations of lionfish on coral reefs in their native range., and second, analyze the bacterial communities associated with the external surfaces of lionfish in their native range.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last 25 years lionfish have invaded the reef communities along the US Eastern seaboard, Caribbean Sea, and the Gulf of Mexico. These fish drastically impact the health of native fish populations, and ultimately coral reef diversity. Previous work on the lionfish has focused on the fish within this invaded range. This project, however, went to the source to study lionfish within their native Indo-Pacific environment, specifically the coral reefs of southern Taiwan. Goals of this project were to study lionfish in their native environment in an attempt to recognize behavior shifts that could contribute to their success in the Atlantic. Also, genetic analyses were conducted to identify potential changes in the genetic makeup between the native and invaded populations. Finally, lionfish-associated bacterial communities were assessed in order to understand the dynamics of invasive species-associated microbial communities. Previous work conducted in our lab has shown that lionfish host a diverse bacterial community, which has historically contributed to disease resistance of the host. Results of this study showed that individual lionfish behaved similarly in the native range as they do in the invaded range, but there was a higher diversity of lionfish species in the Indo-Pacific living relatively closely to each other. This higher diversity in the Pacific could influence population control not seen within the invaded range. Preliminary genetic analysis indicates the possibility of population differentiation based on region within each range and shifts in genetic makeup from native to invaded range. Analyses of the bacterial communities are currently being conducted with preliminary results also indicating differentiation based on geographic location. These results would provide strong evidence of the environmental effect on host-associated bacterial communities. Invasive species are drivers of environmental decline and have negative economic impact. Therefore, understanding invasive species to the fullest may allow for mitigating these effects or preventing future invasions.

This work has been presented to the general public in Taiwan, at scientific conferences, and manuscripts are in preparation. Results will form the basis of talks given to an underserved, rural high school marine science class in central Alabama and a lesson plan presented to fourth graders teaching the scientific process.
